subject: Change ownership of handle to eStorageD object
commitMessage:
Change ownership of handle to eStorageD object

Clients used to create both the CryptHandle and the eStorageD objects
using the same information. Then the client would pass the CryptHandle
into eStorageD methods in order to perform crypto methods. This change
creates the CryptHandle closer to where it is used. This makes the code
simpler and easier to understand.

Tested:
busctl call xyz.openbmc_project.eStoraged.mmcblk0 \
>    /xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/storage/mmcblk0 \
>    xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume FormatLuks ays 3 1 2 3 \
>    xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume.FilesystemType.ext4 \
>    --timeout=60

Change-Id: I276e97146f4498191eb19512bc244a1e8d9cd2cb
Signed-off-by: John Edward Broadbent <jebr@google.com>

I am not satisfied with the testing implications.
This might not be much of a concern, but the downside to changing this is that now CryptHandle needs to be created and destroyed twice.
The second sentence is an incomplete sentence. Maybe we just replace "." with "," and make this 1 sentence instead.
I fixed the sentence by adding a subject. But the semi colon would have worked also.
"The client would then pass the..." sounds a little better for me, but meh it's fine.
Looks like we're hitting a merge conflict
"It was me, John" that caused merged conflict
would it be simpler to just use device.c_str() directly here?

When interacting with C concepts (char array) I would prefer do the conversion (from a string to a char array) as close to the C code as possible. This allows the C++ code to use C++ features.

The caller used to make the c_str() conversion, but I pushed the conversion to the bottom the call stack. It is not required, but I think it is better.

OLD:
client(string)=>CryptHandle(char*)=> init(char*)=>crypt_init(char*)

NEW:
client(string)=>CryptHandle(string)=> init(string)=>crypt_init(char*)

I am not going to die on this hill. If you think it is bad, I can undo it

I think we have a misunderstanding. I'm just saying we can probably skip assigning to const char* that we use once, and instead just call device.c_str() directly in the param:

```
int retval = crypt_init(&cryptDev, device.c_str());
```
shouldn't this just be string_view instead? unless crypt_init might have issue with it.

Thanks for explaining it. I was confused.
And I switched to string_view.
Seems like this defeats the purpose of a string_view. Can you use device.data(), rather than creating a new string?
Yes, Older versions of C++ to guarantee the null termination, but 11 does.  neat
Can you just use devPath directly, rather than create a new string?
